item.title: Putin Is First to Leave G-20 Meeting, as a Cool Wind Blows
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin, who faced criticism from other leaders over Russia’s actions in Ukraine, said he left before the group issued its communiqué because he had to be rested for work Monday.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER and JENNY ANDERSON
item.media:description: President Obama and President Vladimir V. Putin at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation summit in Beijing last week.

item.title: International Education: Number of Academic Refugees Grows
item.description: In recent years, the dangers facing intellectual dissidents and universities in troubled regions like the Middle East have reached a crisis point.
item.category: Global Coalition to Protect Education From Attack
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By AISHA LABI | THE CHRONICLE OF HIGHER EDUCATION
item.media:description: The aftermath of an explosion at Aleppo University in Syria last year. An expert said centers of learning there had become battlegrounds.

item.title: International Education: M.I.T. Settles In for Long Haul in Singapore
item.description: The Massachusetts Institute of Technology has a long-term relationship in Singapore that involves managing five labs with 40 Ph.D. and post-doc researchers.
item.dc:creator: By JANE A. PETERSON
item.media:description: Singapore-M.I.T. Alliance for Research and Technology, or Smart, is a team of professors that manages five laboratories paid for by the Singapore government.

item.title: ISIS Video Purports to Prove Peter Kassig, a U.S. Aid Worker, Was Executed
item.description: The footage released Sunday, which the Islamic State said showed it had executed Mr. Kassig, is significantly different from those of four other executions by the group.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.media:description: Peter Kassig with a truck filled with supplies for Syrian refugees in an undated photograph provided by the Kassig family.

item.title: Afghan Lawmaker Survives Attack That Kills 3 People in Kabul
item.description: The lawmaker who was apparently the target of the attack, Shukria Barakzai, is an outspoken legislator who has campaigned for women’s rights and has run an underground schools for girls.
item.dc:creator: By JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN
item.media:description: A bomb crater created by the suicide attack in Kabul on Sunday.

item.title: Stretch of New High-Speed Rail Opened in Restive Western China
item.description: The new rail will help open up the region of Xinjiang, a critical part of China's economy strategy beset by worsening ethnic violence.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: Iraq and U.S. Find Some Potential Sunni Allies Have Already Been Lost
item.description: The United States and the Iraqi government want to enlist Sunni tribes to fight the Islamic State, but many of them have already been co-opted or conquered.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: In Shift, Pakistanis Fleeing War Flow Into Beleaguered Afghanistan
item.description: Pakistani military’s continuing offensive against Islamist militants in the North Waziristan tribal region has forced an exodus of at least 1.5 million residents.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL and FAROOQ JAN MANGAL

item.title: Kakha Bendukidze Dies at 58; Pushed Post-Soviet Market Change
item.description: Mr. Bendukidze, a biologist and later a wealthy businessman in the final years of the Soviet Union, became an architect of economic and governmental changes in his native Georgia.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Open Source: A New Holiday Tradition for the Dutch: Arguing About Blackface
item.description: A celebration of St. Nicholas in the Netherlands now includes an annual fight over the traditional depiction of his dark-skinned helper, Black Pete.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: Ton van Kesteren, Matthijs Jansen and Dennis Ram of the far-right Dutch Freedom Party attended a meeting in Groningen this month dressed as Black Pete.

item.title: Oil Dispute Takes a Page From Congo’s Bloody Past
item.description: Virunga National Park in the Democratic Republic of Congo has become a battleground pitting economic development against environmentalism.
item.dc:creator: By JEFFREY GETTLEMAN
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: Water being fetched from Lake Edward in Virunga National Park. If oil is found beneath the lake, the park map may be redrawn.

item.title: In Malaysia, Activists Draw Attention to Colonial-Era Sedition Act
item.description: The Sedition Act, a British colonial-era law, is being used to charge and investigate politicians, activists, academics and students. But a law professor is challenging its constitutionality.
item.dc:creator: By POH SI TENG

item.title: A Familiar Anger Begins to Boil Again in Mexico
item.description: The shocking reports about the mass disappearance of college students have stoked the anger of many Mexicans toward corrupt politicians and police officers.
item.dc:creator: By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD
item.media:description: Protesters in Mexico City on Friday carried images of the 43 college students from Iguala who are missing and presumed killed.

item.title: After Three Days on the Town in New York, European Sailors Head Home
item.description: More than 450 marines and sailors from Holland, Spain and England were set to depart after a three-day shore leave in New York City.
item.dc:creator: By PATRICK McGEEHAN
item.media:credit: Jake Naughton for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Dutch warship H.N.L.M.S. Johan de Witt, the the second-largest vessel in the Royal Netherlands Navy, was docked at the passenger ship terminal on the West Side of Manhattan on Friday evening.

item.title: Islamic State Says It Plans to Issue Its Own Currency
item.description: The leaders of the Islamic State have created their own currency, part of a grandiose plan to restore the caliphate era that dominated the Middle East more than 1,300 years ago.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: In Egypt, Jihadists Release Video of an October Attack
item.description: The 30-minute video was the first to be released by the militant group, Ansar Beit al-Maqdis, since publicly declaring its affiliation on Monday with the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: By KAREEM FAHIM and MERNA THOMAS
item.media:description: President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi in October. A jihadist group sent a threatening message to him via a video released on Friday.

item.title: Top General Arrives in Baghdad to See U.S. Contribution in Fight Against ISIS
item.description: On his first visit to Baghdad since the beginning of the American-led military campaign against the Islamic State, Gen. Martin E. Dempsey said he wanted to get a sense of how the troops were doing.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Gen. Martin E. Dempsey met with General Babakir Zebari of Iraq in Baghdad on Saturday.

item.title: Listening Post: Finishing Asia Tour, Obama Promotes More Ambitious Foreign Policy
item.description: The scorecard for President Obama’s Asia trip looks drastically different from the last one, with a landmark climate-change agreement and a trade deal with China.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: President Obama and Angela Merkel, the German leader, at a Group of 20 meeting in Brisbane.

item.title: Putin Gets a Cool Reception From G-20
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia faced a chorus of criticism at a summit meeting, where the fighting in Ukraine threatened to overshadow talk of global economics.
item.dc:creator: By EMMA G. FITZSIMMONS
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin on Saturday in Brisbane.

item.title: Pakistanis Optimistic on Ties After Afghan Leader’s Visit
item.description: As President Ashraf Ghani met with Pakistan’s prime minister on Saturday, officials were upbeat about a possible reset in the relationship.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: Ashraf Ghani, the new president of Afghanistan, left, with Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif during a cricket match on Saturday.

item.title: Hong Kong Activists Kept From Flying to Beijing
item.description: The students calling for free elections had proposed a meeting with China’s prime minister, but they were turned away Saturday at the Hong Kong airport.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY and ALAN WONG
item.media:description: A protester with an umbrella at Hong Kong International Airport on Saturday.

item.title: Obama Offers Assurances of U.S. Shift Toward Asia
item.description: Visiting Australia, President Obama said the United States could be a force for order as Asia faced threats like a nuclear-armed North Korea and disputes between China and its neighbors.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER

item.title: Alexander Grothendieck, Math Enigma, Dies at 86
item.description: His gift for abstraction excavated new ground in algebraic geometry and supplied a theoretical foundation for the solving of some of the most vexing conundrums of modern mathematics.
item.dc:creator: By BRUCE WEBER and JULIE REHMEYER

item.title: Spacecraft on Comet Drills for Data as Its Power Fades
item.description: The Philae lander performed two tricky maneuvers on Friday: drilling into the comet’s rocky surface and rotating itself to try to catch more sunlight to recharge its batteries.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: City in Ukraine Tied to Masochism Finds Link Painful, Sure, but Some Like It
item.description: Residents of the western Ukrainian city of Lviv are of two minds on the reputation of Leopold von Sacher-Masoch.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A waitress at the Masoch Cafe in Lviv, Ukraine, pouring a drink into the mouth of a customer voluntarily tied to a chair.
